project.name: SELinux
project.description: SELinux is a system of mandatory access controls. SELinux can enforce the security policy over all processes and objects in the system.
project.longdescription: This project manages SELinux support in Gentoo. This includes providing kernels with SELinux support, providing patches to userland utilities, writing strong Gentoo-specific default profiles, and deploying policies from Portage.
project.goals: The intention of the project is to make SELinux available to more users. Policy should be available for common daemons, and files merged in from Portage should have the correct file context. Currently we only work on servers, but desktops will be supported in the future.

body.p: Security-Enhanced Linux (SELinux) is a system of mandatory access control using type enforcement and role-based access control. It is implemented as a Linux Security Module (LSM). The team currently supports the 2.4 version, which is only available on x86. The next kernel version, 2.6, will have SELinux and LSM included, and should work across most architectures. The SELinux team will be supporting more architectures, such as PPC with 2.6. In addition to the security module, SELinux consists of a library (libselinux) and userland utilities for compiling policy (checkpolicy), and loading policy (policycoreutils), in addition to other user programs.

project.extraproject: SELinux policy for the core system, including users, administrators, and daemons in the system profile.
project.plannedproject: Profiles, installation guides, and support for non-x86 architectures.
SELinux support on destktops. This involves enhancements to XFree's security, and accompanying policy.

body.p: To participate in the SELinux project first join the mailing list at gentoo-hardened@gentoo.org. Then ask if there are plans to support something that you are interested in, propose a new subproject that you are interested in or choose one of the planned subprojects to work on. You may talk to the developers and users in the IRC channel #gentoo-hardened on irc.freenode.net for more information or just to chat about the project or any subprojects. If you don't have the ability to actively help by contributing work we will always need testers to use and audit the SELinux policies. All development, testing, and productive comments and feedback will be greatly appreciated.

The critical component of a SELinux system is having a strong policy. The team does its best to support as many daemons as possible. However, we cannot create policies for daemons with which we are unfamiliar. But we are happy to receive policy submissions for consideration. There are a few requirements:

ul.li: Make comments (in the policy and/or bug), so we can understand changes from the NSA example policy.
The policy should cover common installations. Please do not submit policy for odd or nonstandard daemon configurations.
We need to know if the policy is dependent on another policy (for example rpcd is dependent on portmap) other than base-policy.

An ebuild for the policy can also be submitted to help the developers integrate the policy into portage more quickly, if it is accepted. See current daemon policies in portage for example uses of the selinux-policy eclass.

body.p:
The policy should be submitted on bugzilla. Please attach the .te and .fc files separately to the bug, not as a tarball. The bug should be assigned to
pebenito@gentoo.org.
